Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints and compliance checklists spread out before me, the hum of the office a familiar background. My phone buzzed with a message from my daughter: “Dad, can you call tonight? Jamie started her new job and wants to tell you all about it!” I smiled, picturing my granddaughter’s eager face, but my eyes drifted back to the audit schedule pinned to my monitor. The audit was months away, but the new safety regulations were dense, and I’d promised myself I’d get ahead on the documentation this week. My team relied on me to set the standard, to catch every detail before the auditors did. Yet, my family expected me to be present, to celebrate milestones and nurture those bonds. I felt the tug in both directions—my granddaughter’s excitement, my team’s trust. The weight of responsibility pressed on me, and I stared at the phone, torn between the warmth of family and the rigor of my profession, unsure which call to answer first.
